author: karalabe
content:
We've been debating the eth/6x versions for typed transactions a lot today and kind of arrived to two possible options for the Geth team. Both work for us, so please weigh in as which option would you prefer we do:

Option A: We roll out 66 (request id), 67 (typed tx in blocks, tx-announce etc)
 - Drawback: Everyone must implement 65 (tx hashes), 66 and 67 before Berlin.
 - The entire network can drop support for eth<67 after the hard fork passes.

Option B: We allow typed transactions in earlier eth protocol versions.  **BUT**
 - Geth will implement 66 (request id), before Berlin. So after Berlin, all Geth nodes on the network will guaranteed speak eth/66.  
 - Geth will drop eth/63 this year, eth/64 by spring 2021 and eth/65 by summer 2021

Either way, **Geth will drop support for anything but the latest eth protocol by next year summer**.

As it stand today, the Geth codebase around syncing is severely limited by all the backwards compatibility required to serve and query old protocol versions. Up until now this was fine-ish as the chain was relatively locked in, but with Eth2 around the corner, we need to open up the chain synchronization too to new models required by the beacon-chain chain selection. We don't want to tiptoe around legacy things that we haven't used in years.

cc <@!211091239112671234> <@!194432762315407360> If you have anything to add

PS: For us Option A is a lot simpler and less error prone, but we're offering up Option B as a courtesy for other client teams to not have to focus on networking too for Berlin.

content: Besu wants to do Option B. We don't want to rush into the implementations of all the new eth protocols with the eth/67 cliff at the end.
